awd_abstract_narration:
The Antarctic Peninsula and West Antarctica are focus areas for climate change. With up to several meters of sea level rise potentially resulting from melting of this region in the coming decades to centuries, the climate trajectory of this region is clearly of global relevance. If surface, or ocean basal melting becomes a significant component of the surface mass balance, it could contribute to the weakening of fringing ice shelves with a resulting marked acceleration of currently grounded ice stream discharging into the Southern Ocean. Thus, better understanding of the climate warming in West Antarctica has strong scientific and societal justification.

The project will combine existing temperature records from manned and automatic weather stations, satellite data, ERA interim reanalysis, and the perspective provided by recent (~200) yr ice core (borehole) data  reconstructed into the WRF model to yield high resolution (10km) surface temperature history  throughout the West Antarctic Ice sheet (WAIS). This will help resolve recent disagreement on the extent of warming in the WAIS region.  Additional comparisons of the climate reconstructions with and without the influences of satellite records on the reconstructions will also be investigated.

por.por_cntn:
The near-surface air temperature trends all over the Antarctic continent were reconstructed from the temperature records at 15 stations scattered mostly around the edge of the continent, and for the first time provided a detailed description of temperature changes in West Antarctica (see Figure, left side of each plot). For the period 1958-2012 (55 years), year-round warming in West Antarctica has been pronounced while slight warming has occurred in East Antarctica (right hand side of each plot in the Figure). The warming of the Antarctic Peninsula is maximized in winter (June-July-August or JJA) but in central West Antarctica spring (September-October-November or SON) has the peak warming, reflecting the different governing mechanisms. During southern summer (December-January-February or DJF), slow warming is widespread across West Antarctica.

During January 2016, a huge melting event took place on the Ross Ice Shelf and the Marie Byrd Land part of West Antarctica.  This coincided with one of the strongest El Niño events yet recorded. These warm phases of El Niño -Southern Oscillation (ENSO) tend to move warm air toward the temperature-sensitive Ross Ice Shelf. At the same time during January 2016, the Southern Annular Mode (SAM) was strongly positive which usually blocks the poleward movement of warm air. A tug of war was underway between these opposing influences with the El Niño impact finally winning around the middle of the January 2016, leading to the widespread melting. Understanding the roles of ENSO and SAM in such Antarctic surface melting events is key to inferring their future likelihood. The predicted future of more extreme and frequent El Niño events in the tropical Pacific Ocean could mean more prolonged and intense summer melt events over the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) as a result of remote Antarctic atmospheric impacts (teleconnections). Recent modeling has suggested that WAIS could be particularly sensitive to surface melting leading to ice sheet disintegration and major sea level rise. The present research shows how such melting could occur and why.

Reference for Figure Caption:

Nicolas, J. P., and D. H. Bromwich, 2014: New reconstruction of Antarctic near-surface temperatures: Multidecadal trends and reliability of global reanalyses. J. Climate, 27, 8070-8093, doi: 10.1175/JCLI-D-13-00733.1.
